Group Actions

What are group actions?

At the very beginning of this course, we were instructed to de-abstractify groups by thinking of them as something that rotates a Rubik's Cube. (Rubik's Cubes were only invented in the 1970s, which means people in the 1960s probably learned group theory using disco balls.) Then we were taught the virtues of groups as abstract objects, where we shoved about 710e697^{10^{e^{69}}}710e69 different definitions of amusing words like "homomorphisms" down our throats and refused to acknowledge the existence of real-world things like triangles or cubes.

Unfortunately, now we have to think of groups as something that rotates or flips or changes a real-world object again. This course is flip-flopping more than an American politician during election season, and it's cutting down on my already-limited will to live.

I HAVE A THEORY. What if Abel, Galois, etc., etc., didn't die of stupid things like getting sick or going to a duel, but instead died out of disgust from studying group theory too much? I have a sample size of 2, so it's a scientifically-proven fact - group theorists all die tragically eaarly deaths.

The permutation group contains all the ways you could change the order of a set. The dihedral group contains all the symmetries of a polygon. When a group element is interpreted as a way to modify some object such that the remains symmetric, i.e. the modification preserves some structure of the object - the number of elements in a set, the space a polygon occupies - we call it a

Definition. Group action. A group action of a group GGG on a set of nnn elements XXX (which may represent letters, numbers, the vertices of a polygon, etc., etc.) is a way to interpret every element of GGG as a permutation of that set. More formally, it is the homomorphism

ϕ(g), ϕ:G→Sym(X)\phi(g),\ \phi: G \to \text{Sym}(X)ϕ(g), ϕ:G→Sym(X)

where Sym(X)=Sn\text{Sym}(X) = S_nSym(X)=Sn​ is the symmetric group of XXX, containing all possible permutations of the nnn elements of XXX.

(A quick nota bene: "symmetry", i.e. "symmetric group", means in this context "something which maps a set onto itself" - i.e. keeping the stuff inside something exactly the same, though not necessarily the order. Just like what that one back-alley doctor did to my organs after an appendicitis surgery.)

For instance, suppose that {1,2,3}\{1,2,3\}{1,2,3} represent the three vertices of a triangle placed upright in clockwise order, with 111 at the top; then the element e2iπ3e^{\frac{2i\pi}{3}}e32iπ​, a rotation by 120 degrees counterclocckwise, would permute the set of vertices into {2,3,1}\{2,3,1\}{2,3,1}. Thus, it maps straightforwardly onto the permutation (123)(123)(123); and so do all other elements of either the cyclic group C3C_3C3​ or the dihedral group D6D_6D6​. The simplest example of a group action is the trivial action: every element in GGG maps to the "do-nothing" permutation. This is an action that says it's an action but does nothing in reality, which is what my mom says about me every weekend.

(Remember that XXX is not a group; it is a set!)

Proof.

In essence, our proof needs to show two things: 1) that the above three properties are necessary and sufficient to define a homomorphism ϕ\phiϕ, and 2) ϕ\phiϕ maps from GGG to Sym(X)\text{Sym}(X)Sym(X). From the last property, we have

ϕ(gh)(x)=ϕ(g)ϕ(h)(x)\phi(gh)(x) = \phi(g)\phi(h)(x)ϕ(gh)(x)=ϕ(g)ϕ(h)(x)

and thus

ϕ(g⋅Gh)=ϕ(g)ϕ(h)\phi(g\cdot_G h) = \phi(g) \phi(h)ϕ(g⋅G​h)=ϕ(g)ϕ(h)

Now to prove that ϕ(g)\phi(g)ϕ(g) maps to Sym(X)\text{Sym}(X)Sym(X). Define ϕ(g)(x)\phi(g)(x)ϕ(g)(x) as a function that maps xxx to θ(g,x)\theta(g,x)θ(g,x); by definition, this is a permutation on XXX if it maps from the set XXX to itself and is also invertible (a bijection, i.e. one-to-one - permuting every element in XXX to another unique element). By rule (1), θ(g,x)\theta(g,x)θ(g,x) maps to XXX; by rule (2), we have

for any g∈Gg \in Gg∈G, thus making ϕ(g)−1\phi(g)^{-1}ϕ(g)−1 the inverse of ϕ(g)\phi(g)ϕ(g) with ϕ(g)\phi(g)ϕ(g) being invertible. Therefore, ϕ(g)∈Sym(X)\phi(g) \in \text{Sym}(X)ϕ(g)∈Sym(X).

The reverse statement results by a straightforward application of the definition of a homomorphism.

Definition. Kernel of an action. The kernel of a group action GGG on XXX, given by a homomorphism ϕ:G→Sym(X)\phi: G \to \text{Sym}(X)ϕ:G→Sym(X), is the kernel of the homomorphism ϕ\phiϕ: it is all group elements ggg taken to the identity permutation.

Note that an application of the FIRST ISOMORPHISM THEOREM!!! shows that, as ϕ\phiϕ is a homomorphism, the quotient group G/Ker(ϕ)G/\text{Ker}(\phi)G/Ker(ϕ) is isomorphic to the image of ϕ\phiϕ (or, in other words, a subgroup of Sym(X)\text{Sym}(X)Sym(X).)

Some group actions are perfectly suited to the set they act on: for instance, the dihedral group D2nD_{2n}D2n​ is isomorphic to the symmetric group of the set of vertices of its corresponding nnn-gon. The kernel of these group actions is the identity alone, as they map perfectly to the symmetric group; call these group actions

Definition. Faithful. A group action is faithful if its kernel is exactly {eG}\{e_G\}{eG​}.

This is why you should be cuddling in bed with Dummit and Foote's Abstract Algebra rather than with a romantic partner: girlfriends and boyfriends cheat, but (a few) group actions are always faithful. (Coincidentally, group actions are also the only action mathematicians are probably ever going to get.)
